description: Partly borrowed from Middle French sisteme, systeme, partly directly from its etymon Late Latin systēma (“harmony; musical scale; set of celestial objects; set of troops; system”), from Ancient Greek σύστημα (sústēma, “musical scale; organized body; whole made of several parts or members”), from σῠνίστημῐ (sunístēmi, “to combine, organize”) + -μᾰ (-ma, resultative suffix). σῠνίστημῐ is from σῠν- (sun-, “with, together”) + ἵστημι (hístēmi, “to stand”), from Proto-Indo-European *steh₂- (“to stand (up)”).
Cognate with Dutch systeem, modern French système, German System, Italian sistema, Portuguese sistema, Spanish sistema.

definitionGroups.group: A collection of organized things; a whole composed of relationships among its members. [from early 17th c.]

entries.meaning: (derogatory) Preceded by the word the: the mainstream culture, controlled by the elites or government of a state, or a combination of them, seen as oppressive to the individual.
(computing) A set of hardware and software operating in a computer.
(mathematics) A set of equations involving the same variables, which are to be solved simultaneously.
(music) A set of staves linked by a brace that indicate instruments or sounds that are to be played simultaneously.
(physiology) A set of body organs having a particular function.
examples: the digestive system  the nervous system

entries.meaning: (psychiatry) A set of alters, or the multiple (“the individual with multiple personalities due to, for example, a dissociative personality disorder”) who contains them.
(astronomy) A planetary system; a set of planets orbiting a star or star system
(philosophy) A comprehensive and logically organized set of propositions or philosophical beliefs.
(role-playing games) A set of rules for a tabletop roleplaying game.
A method or way of organizing or planning.
examples: Followers should have a system to follow that works in their interests, not against them.
